appearances.snippet: what a lineup congressman derrick van orden. not only are we going to be talking about him in washington, but what he did as a navy seal and his operations in venezuela in the past, how he relates to what we just saw over the last 48 hours. senator dave mccormick, he was on an operation in panama for george h.w. bush when he was a captain. he's going to talk about now as a sitting senator and where we go from here as a member of armed services. and, sid rosenberg, why is our new mayor weighing in on foreign policy? yeah, new york city mayor and foreign policy doesn't usually mix. but first, the fastest, most impactful monologue in america more than 20 years, the top three national security threats, i would say facing the united states have lingered. they have languished and kicked down the road with half measures, flip flopping strategies, empty threats and bad compromises. and, in my view, flimsy deals. three chronic dangers are clear. you got iran's terror network and now nuclear ambitions. you got china's threat to taiwan's s

appearances.title: CNN News Central : CNNW : January 8, 2026 11:00am-12:00pm PST
appearances.snippet: we're joined now from capitol hill by republican congressman derrick van orden of wisconsin. he's a former senior chief in the navy seals. the first enlisted seal ever elected to congress. congressman, are you comfortable with this idea of u.s. oversight of venezuela lasting years? >> what i'm comfortable with is making sure that we follow through with the commitment to allow the venezuelan people to have self-determination. i do not support uniform military members conducting ground operations, combat operations in venezuela. what i do support is making sure that we can use all the elements of the united states government to facilitate freedom in venezuela, and however long that takes. you know, i can't answer that question. it's going to be an iterative process to move. >> okay. but there's of course, a possibility that this could involve the u.s. military. it already has involved the u.s. military. so it seems that option could be on the table. and just to be clear about this, i mean, you or someone in congress with a very unique perspective, you spent decades in the seal

appearances.snippet: derrick van orden, let's talk about this for a second. he voted with democrats on something.he other day. now he was a guy who wasn't showing up at his own town hall meetings some time ago. what what do you make of this? >> i think that he is concerned about reelection. he is not concerned about a thoughtful path for having long term health care solutions. he hasn't. he's voted for this to expand the aca tax credits when it was convenient. but on the other side of his mouth, he's talking about how he wants to repeal obamacare. and that's, again, he has aa1 sentence health care policy. and we need more than that. we expect more from from our elected leaders. and i think somebody like derrick van orden has failed to host any sort of in-person town hall to be accountable for any of the votes that he's taken, you know, including his vote for the reconciliation bill. i've been talking to a lot of rural hospital ceos across my district. i'm obviously not their elected representative now. but what do you need? what do you need to keep your doors open? how can we change medicaid and

appearances.title: CNN News Central : CNNW : January 9, 2026 4:00am-5:00am PST
appearances.snippet: the obamacare subsidies here. , which is actually a pretty big number and includes people like derrick van orden, rob wittman, mike carey, you know, jake, your friend jake sherman over a punchbowl. these are not your normal republicans who break from the president on what's considered to be more moderate issues here. what are those numbers? and those people tell you, doug. >> it tells me that they're looking at what the numbers are going to be for obamacare costs. my premiums went up $90 a month. i just paid that yesterday. and they're seeing and hearing from their constituents that they're concerned about this, who don't want to foot bigger and bigger health care bills. and ultimately, yes, on some level, this is defying donald trump. but it also may be helping trump and helping congressional republicans who are looking at election year that historically we know shouldn't go well for republicans. >> what do you think about that, simon >> yeah, i think we saw four votes yesterday in one day where the republicans rebuked the president. there were three votes in the house. there was a significant

appearances.title: Katy Tur Reports : MSNOW : January 9, 2026 11:00am-1:00pm PST
appearances.snippet: you had, you know, a guy like derrick van orden, who's a conservative in a swing seat in wisconsin.ed about this issue and that the white house and the and the republican congressional leadership is not doing enough on the biggest issue facing voters, which is affordability, its affordability crisis. voters aren't worried about venezuela. they're not worried about greenland. they're worried about, you know, paying for health insurance, paying for food, paying car, paying for all that stuff. >> all right. so, david, is the white house concerned about any of this? what are they telling you? >> well, look, i mean, the president it's more about personalization, right? i mean, look, no white house likes to be defined by their own party on capitol hill. that's an age old thing. but this president sort of takes a personal affront to the idea that any republican would do anything different than what he wanted at any given time. there have been past presidents that don't like it, but they understand that sometimes members of their own party have to distance themselves from them. they want to

appearances.title: Velshi : MSNOW : January 10, 2026 7:00am-10:00am PST
appearances.snippet: votes for ringing endorsements of a three year extension of the obamacare subsidies, wisconsin's derrick van orden quote, philosophically, i completely disagree with this, but i'm not going to leave millions of americans who truly need health care insurance in the lurch. end quote. new york's mike lawler said he voted for the bill in order to send it to the senate, which he hopes will tweak it and send a bipartisan version back to the house. indeed, a bipartisan group of senators have spent the week hashing out their own terms for an aca subsidy extension. they appear to maybe be close to agreeing to a pared down version of what the house passed. but there are fissures elsewhere in congress this week. the house attempted but failed to override president trump's vetoes of two bills recently passed by congress. the president vetoed both bills, which, by the way, i'm pretty sure you've never heard of for overtly political reasons. let me explain this to you. last month, donald trump vetoed the miccosukee reservation reserved area act, which would have granted the miccosukee tribe of the florida everg
